Utterance: Hey, Ellie!
Hi! It’s good to see you again. How have things been since our last session?
They’ve been a bit up and down, to be honest.
I appreciate your honesty. Let’s start with the conversation you wanted to have with your dad. How did that go?
It was tough. I tried to express my feelings, but he got defensive.
I’m sorry to hear that. How did you feel during the conversation?
Frustrated and kind of sad. I felt like he wasn’t really listening to me.
That’s understandable. It can be hard when we feel unheard. Did you manage to communicate your feelings despite the defensiveness?
I think I did, but it didn’t go as well as I hoped.
It’s okay. Sometimes, it takes multiple conversations for people to really understand. How do you feel about trying again in the future?
I think I will. I just need to figure out a better way to approach it.
That’s a positive mindset. What do you think you could do differently next time?
Maybe I could choose a different time or setting when he’s more relaxed.
That’s a great idea. It’s important to create an environment that’s conducive to open communication.
Yeah, I’ll definitely keep that in mind.
How about the mentoring at work? Did you reach out to anyone?
I did! I talked to one of my coworkers, and they seemed really receptive.
That’s fantastic! How did that conversation go for you?
It felt good to share my experiences. I think I can help them a lot.
That’s wonderful to hear! It sounds like you’re making strides in helping others. How did that make you feel?
It felt fulfilling. I realized I really enjoy sharing what I know.
That’s great! Helping others can be a powerful way to feel connected and purposeful.
Definitely.
Last time, we talked about being more in touch with your emotions. Have you noticed any changes there?
I’ve been trying to check in with myself more often. It’s hard sometimes, but I’m getting better.
That’s a significant step! What have you noticed about your emotions lately?
I’ve noticed I get anxious before big conversations, like with my dad.
That’s a valuable observation. What do you think contributes to that anxiety?
I think it’s the fear of conflict. I don’t want to hurt his feelings.
That’s understandable. It’s natural to want to protect others' feelings, but remember, your feelings are important too.
Right.
How do you usually cope with that anxiety before a conversation?
I try to breathe and remind myself to stay calm.
Those are good techniques. Have you considered practicing mindfulness or grounding techniques to help further?
I haven’t, but that sounds helpful.
Mindfulness can help you stay present and reduce anxiety. Would you like to try a simple breathing exercise together?
Sure!
Okay, let’s take a deep breath in for four counts... hold it for four... and exhale for four. Let’s do that a couple of times.
<deep breath> Okay, that felt nice.
Great! Practicing that before difficult conversations can help you feel more centered.
I’ll definitely try that.
As we wrap up today, what goals would you like to set for the upcoming week?
I want to keep working on my emotional awareness and try the breathing exercise before my next conversation.
Those sound like excellent goals! I’m excited to hear how it goes next time.
Me too! Thanks for all your help, Ellie.
You’re very welcome! Take care, and I look forward to our next session.
Bye!
Goodbye!
